name: quicklime production, in pieces, loose | quicklime, in pieces, loose | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/1391/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of quicklime in pieces, obtained by calcination of crushed limestone. This form of quicklime can then be sent for grinding to obtain milled quicklime. Quicklime is used for soil stabilisation in the road construction industry, as a building material, as a process material in the chemical and sugar industries, in the iron and steel industry where it is used as an additive for the formation of slag in electric furnaces, and for the treatment of wastewater.;The inventory is based on data from one company located in Switzerland, and on literature. The infrastructure data is estimated based on a tour and sketches of the process, and normalized with a annual production capacity of about 75'000 tons of product per year.;References:;Kellenberger D., Althaus H.-J., Jungbluth N., Künniger T., Lehmann M. and Thalmann P. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Building Products. Data v2.0. ecoinvent report No. 7. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.

From the reception of crushed limestone at the factory gate.

This activity ends with the production of quicklime. The dataset includes the calcination process, the electricity consumption for preheating the heavy fuel oil and the total heating energy for 'production' and 'administration'. The infrastructure and the measured emissions are also included.
category: C:Manufacturing/23:Manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products/239:Manufacture of non-metallic mineral products n.e.c./2394:Manufacture of cement, lime and plaster

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data is based on a Swiss company.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Data is based on the Swiss current technology. The company KFN works on a technically high level. Two vertical kilns are in use. The fuel for the calcination process is heavy fuel oil.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: The data is based on information from one company.

exchanges.description:
Quicklime is produced by the thermal decomposition of limestone. It consists mainly of calcium oxide. Its quality depends on many factors, including physical properties, degree of sintering and chemical composition. As the most readily available and cost effective alkali, quicklime plays an essential part in a wide variety of industrial processes.

The difference between clinker and quicklime used for products in the binding agent industry is mainly the calcination temperature which is a maximum of 1’450ºC for clinker and a maximum of 1’200ºC for quicklime.

exchanges.description: Estimation, based on literature values. The distribution of the dust emissions to the different categories of sizes are made based on the information of the CEPMEIP-Database and adapted, as the amount of PM2.5 emitted increases when TSP is reduced by filters, which are most effective in retaining the particulates of larger size. The 20% are PM<2.5, the 40% are PM>10 and the rest 40% are 2.5<PM<10.

exchanges.description:
Estimation, based on company data. The fuel used at the respective company (KFN) for calcining is heavy fuel oil. The other companies supplying the Swiss market use different fuel types. This fact is not reflected in the inventory, which focuses on KFN. The representativeness has been adjusted and therefore the uncertainty has increased.

Reference(s):
Kellenberger D., Althaus H.-J., Jungbluth N., Künniger T., Lehmann M. and Thalmann P. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Building Products. Final report ecoinvent Data v2.0 No. 7. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.

exchanges.description: Calculated. The CO2-emission is caused partly by the calcination of limestone and partly by the fuel combustion. Heavy fuel oil has carbon content of 0.849 (from the dataset 'heavy fuel oil, burned in refinery furnace, CH'). The emissions of fossil CO2 are therefore 0.292209626 per kg of CaO. The emissions for the calcination of limestone are calculated to be 0.785714286.
